Award.AwardTitle: REU and RET Site in Physics at The University of Texas at Brownsville
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the continuation of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site in Physics at the University of Texas Brownsville. The site includes a Research Experience for Teachers (RET) component. The REU and RET site will focus on research in frontier areas of phenomenological, experimental and applied physics at state-of-the-art facilities. The goal is to give students and teachers a research experience in the areas of gravitational wave astronomy, optical astronomy, lasers and photonics, materials science, and/or biophysics that will stimulate students' desire to become scientists and give teachers a better understanding of the process of scientific research. The REU and RET programs include a close mentoring and guidance system from the faculty and program management team, fostering interaction and active participation by students and teachers through seminars, lunch meetings, colloquia, professional development workshops, outreach opportunities, and presentations.

In gravitational wave astronomy participants will be given a coherent unified view of the field and will learn the scientific value of both the potential wealth of astrophysical information to be obtained from this new astronomical window and the challenges posed in developing the technological expertise necessary at the instrumental level in opening this new window. In lasers and photonics they will learn of the challenges and promises that this fast evolving discipline holds for new electronics. In biophysics participants will be exposed to state-of-the-art techniques in single molecule spectroscopy and in investigations of the role of amino acids in protein structure and function. In materials science they will learn about thermoelectric materials and their potential use for renewable energy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award allowed the involvement of 24 undergraduate students from different institutions across the country in various research activities. These activities covered the fields of gravitational wave astronomy, optical time domain astronomy, materials science, biophysics and optical physics. Additionally the program offered the opportunity to participate in the experience to 11 local High School Physics teachers. These teachers not only performed research utilizing the university local astronomical telescope but also learn to incorporate the research conducted in the teaching of astronomy at all the Brownsville Independent School district local High Schools.

Six of the local HS teachers are Hispanics as well as nine of the students. 16 of the students participating and 6 of the HS teachers are females. This is a relevant accomplishment in a field were women and ethnic minorities are typically underrepresented.

Participating teachers understood the importance of foundational knowledge as well as the design of meaningful teaching to further learning. Critical elements of science teaching in the 21st century were illustrated in this project, specifically (a) attending to significant disciplinary knowledge and organizing teaching around core concepts; (b) modeling an inquiry approach to teaching that supports metacognitive skills by engaging in systematic observation and discussion to elicit conclusions. 

A relevant contribution of this project also  is that it shows the value of partnerships between the university, and school districts to design and implement innovative and relevant approaches to teach science in the 21st century. Additionally the project took science learning out to the community and public spaces such as the Resaca de la Palma State Park.
